item.title: Formsets, Concurrent Edits and Uncaught Exceptions
item.description:
Description

A lightning talk about fixing three separate bugs in the Django codebase with the same root cause.
item.dc:creator: Brad Martsberger

django-rest-framework and angularjs lightning talk

item.title: A lightning look at O'Reilly's Python books
item.description:
Description

Wouldn't it be awesome if ChiPy wrote its own book? We'd be able to get BEvERages for weeks, maybe months on the royalty! If so, we'd need to see what's already out there.

This lightning talk takes a look at O'Reilly's Python books using requests and BeautifulSoup, with a little of scipy's hierarchical clustering on the book descriptions. It is presented in an iPython notebook.
item.dc:creator: Tanya Schlusser

item.title: Lightning Talks - Sept. 4, 2013
item.description:
Summary

LIGHTNING TALKS: Sept. 04, 2013

The annual tradition of lightning talks has captivated the Django world.

A lightning talk is a chance to say something to (a large subset of) the whole conference. The thing is, lightnings should last "a MAXIMUM of five minutes." Allowing a minute between talks, if each talk averaged THREE minutes there would be time for roughly forty-five talks. So please don't feel that you HAVE to speak for five minutes. Say what you have to say, and stop.
item.dc:creator: Various speakers

item.title: Django advanced cache templatetag
item.description:
Description

Django advanced cache templatetag

Une application django pour gérer le cache de fragments de templates, avec des fonctions avancées : - gestion de version - compression - cache partiel - facilement configurable et extensible - compatible avec le cache par défaut

intervenant: Stéphane Angel

Slides: http://rencontres.django-fr.org/2012/presentations/djangocong-django-adv-cache-tag.pdf

Site: http://rencontres.django-fr.org Realisation: http://www.guillaumebarbaz.com
item.dc:creator: Stéphane Angel

item.title: It's over 9000
item.description:
Description

It's over 9000

Ma page fait 9000 requêtes SQL, pourquoi, et comment je m'en sors ? D'abord, il faut s'en apercevoir avant de passer en production. Ensuite, il existe des techniques classiques, en fonction de la complexité de la situation.

Intervenant: Marc Hertzog

Slides: http://rencontres.django-fr.org/2012/presentations/it-s-over-9000.html

Site: http://rencontres.django-fr.org/ Realisation: http://www.guillaumebarbaz.com
item.dc:creator: Marc Hertzog

item.title: Raconter vos tests en histoire avec Lettuce
item.description:
Description

Raconter vos tests en histoire avec Lettuce

Vous êtes vous déjà demandé quel est le but d'un test qui échoue ? Nous sommes des Djangonautes mais les Rubistes font (rarement) aussi des choses intéressantes, et c'est le cas d'un outil de test Cucumber porté de Ruby à Django nommé Lettuce. Cet outil offre une approche alternative à l'écriture des tests (Behavior Driven Development) qui facilite la réutilisabilité et la compréhension. Chaque test est associé à une simple phrase en language naturel, en composant chacune de ces phrases sous forme d'histoires, vous serez en mesure d'écrire des scénari complexes et facile à maintenir.

Intervenant: Stéphane Raimbault

Slides: http://rencontres.django-fr.org/2012/presentations/lettuce/

Site: http://rencontres.django-fr.org Realisation: http://www.guillaumebarbaz.com
item.dc:creator: Stephane Raimbault

A lightning talk is a short talk, typically only five minutes in duration, providing an opportunity for participants - particularly people not featured in the main programme - to deliver a presentation on a subject of their choosing.

item.title: Wednesday's Lightning Talks
item.description:
Description

EuroPython 2022 - Wednesday's Lightning Talks

[The Auditorium on 2022-07-13]

Signing up is on a first-come-first-served basis. The queue is reset every day in the morning. You may talk about / present (almost) everything with certain boundaries: - no promotion for products of companies, no call for 'we are hiring' (but you may name your employer). - conference announcements are limited to one minute only - one LT per person per conference policy: everyone who has not given an LT at this year's conference, yet, is ahead of you in the queue - keep it short, the shorter the presentations, the more people can give a talk

See you there and have fun!

This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International License http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/4.0/
item.dc:creator: Ram Ranchum

item.title: Python Module of the Month: q
item.description:
Description

Montreal, March 10, 2014 - In this 5-minute lightning talk serial speaker Rory Geoghegan presents the q Python module, a (quote) "Quick-and-dirty debugging output for tired programmers".

Useful links:

  • q: http://sflx.ca/q
  • Rory: http://sflx.ca/rory
  • MP44: http://sflx.ca/mp44e
  • Montreal Python: http://montrealpython.org
  • Savoir-faire Linux: http://www.savoirfairelinux.com
item.dc:creator: Rory Geoghegan

item.title: Module of the Month: csv
item.description:
Description

Montreal, Dec. 9, 2013 - In this lightning talk Python developer Rory Geoghegan presents csv -- a Python module which implements classes to read and write tabular data in CSV format.

Useful links:

  • csv: http://docs.python.org/2/library/csv.html
  • Rory: http://sflx.ca/rory
  • MP42: http://montrealpython.org/en/2013/12/mp42/
  • Montreal Python: http://montrealpython.org
  • Savoir-faire Linux: http://www.savoirfairelinux.com
item.dc:creator: Rory Geoghegan

item.title: Concurrent Testing wiht py.test
item.description:
Description

Introducing a different way to perform concurrent testing with the py.test framework.
item.dc:creator: Reverb Chu

item.title: Insight About Async/Await
item.description:
Description

Slide deck referenced: https://speakerdeck.com/pybay/2017-luciano-ramalho-modern-concurrency
item.dc:creator: Luciano Ramalho

item.title: Best practices on debugging open source library
item.description:
Description

How not to fall into a rabbit hole when debugging mysterious bugs in a large open source library.

Almost everyone uses some open source library, but when that library fails to do what you want - i.e. decoding only 2 pages out of a 4 page pdf file or it just straight up raises an exception.

Many would dive deep into the code. In this talk, I will try to convince you not to do that by sharing my anecdotal experiences such as finding an elusive unicode character encoding difference between two popular OS's from a large open source project.
item.dc:creator: Jouella Fabe

item.title: Calculating the Epicenter of an Earthquake with Python
item.dc:creator: Gabrielle Simard-Moore

item.title: Dangers of Django
item.description:
Description

Django's data integrity pitfalls and how to avoid them
item.dc:creator: Alex Becker

item.title: Deep Learning for Conservation
item.description:
Description

iNaturalist recently integrated computer vision into their apps, providing automatic species suggestions based on visual and spatio-temporal data (i.e. where things have been found before). This is a presentation on how the app works, how it was built (TensorFlow + inception + our dataset), and challenges encountered when integrating deep learning into the expert community of scientists and trained naturalists.
item.dc:creator: Alex Shepard

item.title: Effective retry techniques for working with 3rd party APIs
item.description:
Description

Best practices for using the popular retrying package (https://github.com/jd/tenacity) to handle retry logic with 3rd party APIs.
item.dc:creator: Fabio Fleitas

item.title: Emulating Lazy Evaluation
item.description:
Description

Python does not support lazy evaluation, so lets make Python do lazy evaluation. It's fun and gives us an excuse to do some metaprogramming.
item.dc:creator: Henry Chen

item.title: Growing an Open Source Community from 1 to 300
item.description:
Description

Zulip is an open source alternative to Slack, optimized for productivity. The Zulip project has grown from 1 to 300 contributors in about 18 months, with more commits merged per week than Docker and Django combined. Rich Gupta presents specific, reusable techniques used to build an open source project and make the community successful.
item.dc:creator: Rishi Gupta

item.title: Lost Federal Technical Reports
item.description:
Description

Robert L. Bolin has discovered 100K Federal Technical reports that are not digitized and not indexed online. He proposes using Python to deconstruct and parse the PDF version of the index and create a modern library index giving people intellectual access to those reports.
item.dc:creator: Robert Bolin

item.title: Magic Wormhole
item.description:
Description

Magic Wormhole is the easiest way to send files and directories securely from one computer to another. The talk (briefly) covers the cryptographic algorithms it uses and how it improves on other tools.
item.dc:creator: Brian Warner

item.title: Predict timeline - Generating Agile SW metrics w/ Python
item.description:
Description

Agile methodology is mostly used by project management and software teams for creating a predictable software release timeline. Agile output is measured in form of sprint metrics such as burndown chart, cumulative velocity etc . Usually commercial project management tools provide user stories management and metrics out of the box. Many organizations do not have these expensive tools due to costs and budget or historical choices. This talk describes how daily agile metrics can be generated using Python for any reasonable project management tool that has an Agile template and a webservices API.
item.dc:creator: Meenal Pant

item.title: Python Package Management with pip-tools
item.description:
Description

How to use pip-tools (https://github.com/jazzband/pip-tools) to better manage Python requirement files
item.dc:creator: Fabio Fleitas

item.title: STDIO Game Jam
item.description:
Description

Oakland's video game museum will host a hackathon to create small, complete game programs that beginners can read. These text-based games only use stdio, so they're easy for beginners to read.
item.dc:creator: Al Sweigart

item.title: Taking the __magic__ out of Python classes
item.description:
Description

A peek into the internals of Python classes. Including the world's quickest introduction to metaclasses.
item.dc:creator: Henry Chen

https://tw.pycon.org/2015apac/zh/schedule/
